title: More Than Mood Swings

content: When most people think of bipolar disorder, they imagine a person smiling one moment and crying the next.
I’ve experienced that during mixed episodes. But that barely scratches the surface of what bipolar disorder really is. It’s so much more complex.
Bipolar disorder is impulsive spending sprees that seem like great ideas at the moment, racing thoughts at 2 a.m., and days when you spend 14 hours in bed.
This condition affects nearly every part of my life, from my energy levels to how well I sleep. Here’s some of what I’ve experienced beyond mood swings.

sections.heading: Distortions in Reality
content: Many people aren’t aware of this, but psychosis is fairly common in bipolar disorder. It’s something that I’ve experienced on several occasions.

I couldn’t tell what was real and what my mind had created. Psychosis can be terrifying because you are convinced something is true when it isn’t. And often, you don’t realize it’s happening until later.

sections.heading: Grandiosity
content: Grandiosity sometimes goes along with psychosis. I’ve experienced it during bipolar episodes. I had a deep conviction that I was destined for something huge. In my mind, every sign or coincidence pointed toward it. The signs weren’t real, though. My mind created them.

sections.heading: Anxiety
content: During manic episodes, anxiety can spike sky high. Overstimulation and a lack of sleep may put your body into the “fight or flight” mode. This can make you feel tense and uncomfortable. I’ve had anxiety so bad that I ended up in the emergency room. My blood pressure and heart rate would be high, too. The result of stress hormones flooding my brain and body.

sections.heading: Irritability
content: One of the least-talked-about symptoms is irritability. But it’s one of the diagnostic criteria for bipolar disorder. It’s something I experience during hypomanic and manic episodes. My thoughts start racing, and everything seems overwhelming. Before I know it, that turns into sharp-edged irritability.

sections.heading: Brain Fog
content: Brain fog was one of the first symptoms I had. I still experience it, even during periods of stability. It’s not a lack of motivation. It’s a memory issue. I’ll forget what I just did 10 minutes ago or have problems focusing during conversations, when listening to others used to be my superpower.

content: When I play pickleball, I’ll forget whether or not I just served. My teammates give me that puzzled look, the kind that says, “Is everything OK?” I wish I could explain that my brain just isn’t working like it used to.

sections.heading: Impulsivity
content: During mania, my brain hits the gas. I’ll say and do things without thinking, things that aren’t safe or that I might be really embarrassed about later. I’ve tried to buy an expensive new car, sell my house, and travel to faraway places. The aftermath of these decisions can bring regret, embarrassment, financial stress, and even confusion over how it escalated so quickly.

sections.heading: Catatonia
content: Hardly anyone talks about catatonia with bipolar disorder, but I’ve experienced it on several occasions. Catatonia is a neuropsychiatric syndrome that involves reduced movement (or immobility), lethargy, mutism, and bizarre body postures. It can even be deadly, in some cases. It can affect basic physical functions, like hydration, eating, and bladder control.

content: Catatonia may seem like depression, but it’s different. It's like your brain is no longer telling your body to move or your mouth to speak. I was sent to the emergency room during one episode. I tried to speak to the doctors, but the words wouldn’t come. I tried to use my laptop during another episode, but my fingers wouldn’t even move across the trackpad.
The last time was so severe that I was hospitalized. Fortunately, there are medications that are pretty effective for catatonia. Once I started treatment, it cleared up for me in about a week.

sections.heading: Final Thoughts
content: Living with bipolar disorder isn’t just about dealing with mood episodes. It’s about managing all of the other things that go along with the condition. It can feel overwhelming at times. Fortunately, there are very effective treatments that make stability not only possible but likely.
